section-block.rac_essential-question: What do we do at school?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: By Mij Kelly and Mary McQuillan
section-block.rac_book_summary: When Suzy Sue goes to preschool, her farm animal friends are worried. After searching for her, they discover that she’s at preschool. They learn that preschool is a safe and fun place to be.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about what they like to do at school. Ask for specific games they like to play or songs they like to sing.
Invite children to sing “This Is the Way We Go to School.” Have children act out the different actions.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Preschool Time by Mij Kelly and Mary McQuillan.
Scout loves all sorts of books, but he especially loves narratives like this one. He enjoys stories with talking animals!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
Why do the animals go to the school?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Suzy Sue’s animal friends couldn’t find her. They searched everywhere.
They called her name, but there was no reply. Why was there no reply?
What different animals do you see on the playground? What are they doing? Does it look like they are having fun?
What do Suzy Sue’s animal friends see when they look inside the preschool?
Look at Suzy Sue’s animal friends faces. How are they feeling?
Look at the animals. Do you think they like the preschool? Why? Why not?
Let’s all pretend that we are the animals at the school. Let’s act out what each animal is doing.
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
Why do the animals go to the school?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share their thinking.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They want to find Suzy Sue.
They want to learn about preschool.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about school activities as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do the animals miss Suzy Sue or the farm?
What do the animals do when they get to the school?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Young children who are learning more than one language reap many long-term cognitive and social benefits. Create a learning environment where children can use both English and their home language. Let parents know that the use of another language will not delay their children’s growth in English.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Show Self-Awareness
section-block.rac_body-text: When you show self-awareness you tell who you are and describe yourself in different ways. Invite children to describe themselves. Model this for children by describing yourself. Encourage children to use personal and possessive pronouns in their descriptions.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit the book Preschool Time by Mij Kelly and Mary McQuillan. We will talk about how we feel about ourselves.
Clifford likes to describe his feelings and the things he likes to do. One thing he likes to do is read!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
Read aloud the book and the Day 2 prompts.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: The cow is sad because Suzy has gone to preschool.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Think of a time when you missed someone. How did you feel? (MB)
Look at the pictures on these pages. Where are the hens? What are they doing?
Suzy Sue draws pictures and reads books everyday in preschool. This is a routine. What routines do you have at school?
Suzy Sue made a cardboard box boat in preschool. Describe what you like to do in preschool. Do you like to make things, too? (MB)
Suzy Sue tells the cow that the school is designed with children just like her in mind. That means it was made for children just like her! What would you like a preschool made for you to have? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Challenge children to show their self-awareness as they play a game of Who Am I? Ask children to raise their hands when they agree with a list of self-awareness statements, such as: I go to preschool. I live on a farm. I speak Spanish. I like stories with talking animals. I don’t like to eat peanut butter and jelly sandwiches. I like to draw.
Encourage children to use different art materials to draw and decorate a picture that shows the rest of the class something they like to do.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about what they like to do at school.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Self-awareness is a skill that will help children learn about themselves and their feelings. Preschool Time includes many challenging words and phrases to convey feelings. Use feeling words like proud and frustrated to help children recognize their own feelings. (Understood.org/Self-Awareness/Importance)

section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children that Suzy Sue lives on a farm. Ask them to talk about what they know about farms.
Sing “Old McDonald Had a Farm” with children. Point to the different characters in Preschool Time. Identify a sound for each animal in the book before you begin the song.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are reading Preschool Time by Mij Kelly and Mary McQuillan.
This book is about preschool. Scout loves stories that show the different activities that children do at preschool.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What do the animals learn about Suzy Sue’s preschool?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s retell the story so far. Where do you think Suzy Sue is going? Why are the animals searching for her? Where do they search?
The cow tells the sheep that they have to get Suzy Sue back. They can’t just stand there and weep.
What does weep mean? Who can pretend that they are weeping?
The children in the preschool are playing with pretend money.
What do you think they are doing with the pretend money?
The cow says, “We’re going to stay forever now.” How do you think he feels about school now?
What kinds of things do the farm animals see at Suzy Sue’s preschool?
Look at the animals’ faces. How do you think they are feeling? Talk about how each animal feels.
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What do the animals learn about Suzy Sue’s preschool?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They learned that children play with pretend money.
They learned that preschool has books.
They learned that preschool is fun.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about what they like to do at school, inviting children to add end punctuation.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Did they learn that preschool has farm animals or books?
They learned that preschool has b_____ (books).
They learned that preschool has books.
Name three more things the animals learn about preschool.

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Engaging Children in Conversations
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Extend conversations with questions about what children are doing (What are you working on?), asking for explanations (How do you think that happened?), asking children to make predictions (What do you think will happen next?), and asking children to connect learning to their own lives (How did you do that?).

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion about what they know about school rules and why it is important to have rules. Have children identify some of the rules of their school.
Have children sing school rules to the tune of “This is the Way We _____ .” Examples could be: clean the room, raise our hand, listen and learn.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Our School Rules. It is an informational text in the form of a poster.
Scout loves to look at informational posters. He loves to learn new information.
Preschool Time and Our School Rules show us things we do at school. Let’s see if we can find any connections between the two!
As we read the Big Chart of Big Ideas, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
What do we do at school?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart. Then use these prompts to read and discuss the child-facing poster together.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What can we share with others?
Point to the children who are cleaning up. What are they doing? What do you clean up at our school?
Point to the children who are taking turns. Do you think the children in Preschool Time take turns using the pretend money?
Why is it important to listen in class?
How can we be kind at school? How was Suzy Sue kind to her friends? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Choose individual or pairs of children to think of and act out different activities at school that they have learned about this week. Challenge the other children to guess the activity. Help children understand which activities are school rules, such as cleaning up and listening to the teacher.
Provide a writing prompt about what we do at school and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Encourage children to describe what they see in the classroom. The preschool environment may represent multilingual learners’ first unknown social environment. They may have difficulties communicating, following directions, and expressing ideas and feelings. Encouraging children to share what they see will foster free conversation.

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children pretend to be the animal characters as they act out different parts of the story: searching for Suzy Sue, arriving
at the preschool playground, going inside the preschool, seeing Suzy at the preschool, and planning and creating their preschool at the farm.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Preschool Time by Mij Kelly and Mary McQuillan.
This book is a narrative that the authors made up. Scout loves to read made-up stories.
This week we read about Suzy Sue and what her farm animal friends learned about preschool. As I read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
What do the animals do when they come home?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The hens went into the preschool and acted like spies.
They wore a disguise.
Why do you think they were acting as spies? Stand up and show me how you would act like a spy.
Can you tell how the cow feels now? How is that different from how he felt at the beginning of the story?
Suzy Sue and the farm animals are friends. How do we know? Show me how you act with your friends.
What changes do you think the animals made to their farm when they came home? Would you like to live on that farm? Why? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk with a partner about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do the animals do when they come home?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share their thinking.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They thought about what they had learned.
They turned the farm into a preschool.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about what the animals did when they came home to the farm.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Did they make a preschool or a drawing?
Why did the animals make a preschool on the farm?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Learning to retell a story is a skill that will help preschoolers with later reading comprehension. Ask children to talk about what happened in the story, the characters, what they said and did, and the places where they went. Children can retell a story through drawing. Children can draw a picture about something from the story.
